author: Saphora Smith
title: GoFundMe page surpasses £50K goal to bring deported grandmother back to UK
text:
Wednesday 1 March 2017 22:05 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Forced to leave UK: Irene Clennell GoFundMe 
A fundraising campaign to bring back a grandmother who was deported from the UK to Singapore has surpassed its £50,000 goal. 
Irene Clennell was held in a Scottish detention centre in February before being sent back to her country of origin last week. 
The mother-of-two and grandmother-of-one first arrived in London in 1988 and married her husband, John, a British man, two years later. 
She was granted indefinite leave to remain in the UK after her marriage, but periods spent in Singapore caring for her elderly parents appear to have invalidated her residential status. 
Mrs Clennell told the BBC she was put in a van and taken to the airport from the Dungavel Detention Centre in South Lanarkshire last month, without the opportunity to contact her lawyer or get any clothes from her home. 
She has made repeated attempts – both in Singapore and in the UK – to re-apply for permission to live with her husband, who she said is in poor health and needs her as his carer. 
A GoFundMe page set up by Mrs Clennell’s sister-in-law, Angela, has now raised more than £50,000 to pay for legal fees to fight her case. 
In her plea for donations Anglea wrote: “Because of insensitive and unfair government rules, she [Mrs Clennell] has been taken away to a detention centre and has been told she will be deported. Grandmother married to British man for 27 years is deported from UK 
“Her husband John - my brother - is seriously ill and Irene is his sole caretaker. Without her to look after him, we’re all worried for him, and to rip apart a family after 30 years of happiness seems so unfair.” 
She added: “Her whole life is here in Britain. It would be heartbreaking for us all to see her go.” 
A Home Office spokesman told the BBC: "All applications for leave to remain in the UK are considered on their individual merits and in line with the immigration rules. 
"We expect those with no legal right to remain in the country to leave." More about:
